content:
I am trying to upgrade a syntax highlighting library from Lean 3 to Lean 4. And I'd like to know about the current situation of Lean 3.

  • Is there still anyone using Lean 3?
  • Did the syntax changed significantly from Lean 3 to 4? For example, was =>and the fun+match notation valid in Lean 3?

Thanks in advance.
While we can't guarantee that nobody uses lean 3, it's definitely no longer supported, neither the official version, nor the community fork.

Yes, the Lean 4 syntax is significantly different from Lean 3. For example, there's now by instead of begin ... end, plural keywords like variables no longer work (now you just use variable), tactic combinators like <;> now have different syntax, there's way more keywords now, and many more changes.

An additional complication is that now Lean 4's syntax can be dynamically extended and can be arbitrarily complicated. Most keywords in the language are defined or could have been defined with Lean metacode. This means that having perfect syntax highlighting is effectively impossible, but I think that targeting the most commonly used core syntax is probably good enough for most use cases.

I added that bat highlighting originally -- I think doing what I did to get the original PR there, which essentially was just porting the VSCode extension's highlighting, should be doable on vscode-lean4 to emit something for Lean 4 (and yeah I don't think it'd be too bad to just replace the Lean 3 definitions rather than trying to create something that works for both).
(though some information is outdated on that page)

Thank you all! I summarized your responses and fed them back to the bat developers. Just now, they replied that it is ok to drop Lean 3 support.
https://github.com/sharkdp/bat/issues/3286#issuecomment-2858925357
David has marked this topic as resolved.
